Description: Export ban on onions imposed as prices peaked at Rs 70-80 per kg after unseasonal rains damaged crops
Export ban lifted; MEP set at $600 per tonne after prices crashed to Rs 4-12 per kg following bumper harvest
MEP set at $200 per tonne for onion varieties
MEP increased from $200 to $230 per tonne for varieties other than Bangalore Rose and Krishnapuram
Government imposed Minimum Export Price (MEP) of $650 per tonne to curb exports and control rising domestic prices
MEP of $300 per tonne imposed; later increased to $500 per tonne in same month
MEP increased to $300 per tonne (later raised to $500 per tonne in July) to control domestic prices
Stock limits imposed on potato at $450 per MT under Essential Commodities Act
Stock limits imposed on onion and potato under Essential Commodities Act; states empowered to set limits for wholesalers
MEP on potato removed from $450 per MT
MEP maintained at $250 per tonne for onions
MEP increased from $250 to $425 per tonne due to unseasonal rains affecting crop and rising domestic prices
MEP sharply increased from $425 to $700 per tonne to curb exports as wholesale prices at Lasalgaon reached Rs 5,700 per quintal
MEP on onion removed/scrapped to push exports as domestic prices crashed after bumper harvest
MEP raised to $425 per tonne following unseasonal rains and crop damage
MEP further raised to $700 per tonne as prices skyrocketed
MEP of $850 per tonne imposed on Letter of Credit basis effective till December 31, 2017
NAFED procures 13,507.71 MT of onion worth Rs 15.60 crore from Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh under PSF scheme
MEP of $850 per tonne imposed again as domestic prices increased
MEP reduced from $850 to $700 per tonne
MEP on onion removed to encourage exports as domestic prices fell
Onion farmers face distress as late kharif and delayed cultivation leads to surplus in March instead of December-January
Maharashtra government announces Rs 150 crore relief for onion farmers (ex-gratia payment of Rs 200 per quintal for onions sold between Nov 1-Dec 15 at distress prices)
Farmers sell onions at distress prices as low as Rs 1-1.50 per kg; protests intensify across Maharashtra
Maharashtra Cabinet approves Rs 150 crore relief package covering 75 lakh metric tonnes of onions sold at low prices
NAFED procures approximately 57,373 MT of onion during Rabi 2019 for buffer stock
Government directs NAFED to procure 50,000 tonnes of onion for buffer stock under Price Stabilisation Fund
Withdrawal of export incentive on onions under Merchandise Exports from India Scheme (MEIS)
Onion prices start rising by 20% compared to July; government begins close monitoring
MEP of $850 per tonne imposed on Letter of Credit basis to curb shipments as wholesale prices doubled since July
Complete ban on onion exports imposed with immediate effect due to sustained high prices and flood damage in Maharashtra and Karnataka
Stock limits imposed: 100 quintals for retail traders and 500 quintals for wholesale traders across India
Government facilitates import of 1.2 lakh MT of onion and announces tender for imports
Stock limits reduced to 20 quintals for retail and 250 quintals for wholesale traders
NAFED imports 2,950 MT of onion from Egypt and Iran; distributes in Maharashtra, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu
Centre directs NAFED to commence procurement of 40,000-50,000 tonnes for buffer stock; target of 1 lakh tonnes set
Government bans export of all varieties of onion (except cut, sliced or powder) to ensure domestic availability before kharif arrival
Stock limits imposed under Essential Commodities Act: 25 MT for wholesalers and 2 MT for retailers till December 31, 2020
NAFED creates buffer stock of 99,000 tonnes but expects 25% damage (25,000 tonnes) before distribution
Stock limit restrictions on onions expired
Export prohibition lifted via DGFT notification after kharif crop prospects improved
Government releases buffer stock in targeted markets to moderate prices during lean season
NAFED procured over 1 lakh MT onions during 2020-21 for buffer stock under Price Stabilisation Fund from Maharashtra, Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh
Government procured 2.0 lakh tonnes of onion for buffer stock in 2021-22
NAFED releases 32,658 MT of onion from central buffer to stabilize domestic prices
Government procures record 2.5 lakh tonnes of onion for buffer stock 2022-23 (highest till date) from Maharashtra, Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh
Government releases buffer stock in major consumption centres during September 2022 to January 2023
Maharashtra government requests Centre to buy additional 2 lakh tonnes through NAFED as prices crash to Rs 6 per kg
Government increases onion buffer stock target to 3.0 lakh tonnes for 2023-24
40% export duty imposed on onions with immediate effect till December 31, 2023 to improve domestic availability
Government restarts onion procurement at Rs 2,410 per quintal in Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh through NAFED and NCCF
Government steps up sale of buffer onion stock at subsidized rate of Rs 25 per kg in retail markets
Onion farmers in Maharashtra decide to sell directly in markets, bypassing traders due to poor prices
MEP of $800 per tonne imposed on onions till December 31, 2023 to ensure sufficient domestic availability
NAFED and NCCF procure additional 2 lakh tonnes for buffer stock; price realization higher than previous year
Complete ban on onion exports imposed till March 31, 2024 ahead of elections to control inflation
Export ban on onions extended indefinitely beyond March 31, 2024 to maintain domestic availability
Export ban lifted; MEP of $550 per tonne imposed along with 40% export duty
Government procures 4.7 lakh tonnes of onion for buffer stock (compared to 3.0 lakh tonnes previous year) from Maharashtra
MEP of $550 per tonne removed with immediate effect; 40% export duty reduced to 20%
Farmers protest at Lasalgaon APMC climbing water tank demanding removal of MEP as prices drop Rs 300-500 per quintal
Customs duty amendment Notification No. 3/2025-Customs issued on February 1, 2025 related to onion export duty adjustments
Government announces removal of 20% export duty on onions effective April 1, 2025; Notification No. 19/2025-Customs issued by Department of Revenue
PIB notification confirms withdrawal of 20% export duty on onions effective April 1, 2025; Lasalgaon modal prices at Rs 1,330 per quintal
20% export duty on onions completely withdrawn; all export restrictions on onions lifted; expected to revive exports to Bangladesh, UAE, Malaysia, Sri Lanka
Central government decides to procure 3 lakh tonnes of summer onions for 2025-26 buffer stock through NAFED and NCCF; 80% procurement in Maharashtra (Nashik district)

NAFED and NCCF begin onion procurement for 2025-26 buffer stock under Price Stabilisation Fund targeting 0.3 million tonnes at market prices; Lasalgaon prices Rs 15-16 per kg (30% lower than previous year)
Gujarat government announces Rs 124 crore financial aid to 90,000 onion farmers; Rs 200 per quintal assistance for rabi crop sold between April-May 2025 at low prices under Market Intervention Scheme
Government procurement of onions at market prices for 2025-26 buffer stock reaches 23,517 tonnes; average purchase price Rs 16.75 per kg (significantly lower than Rs 29/kg in FY25)
Central government procures 1.07 lakh tonnes of onions so far through NAFED and NCCF; 1.06 lakh tonnes sourced from Maharashtra; total procurement target 3 lakh tonnes
Government launches subsidized onion sale at Rs 25 per kg through NAFED, NCCF and Kendriya Bhandar outlets in Delhi, Mumbai and Ahmedabad; targeted disposal begins due to rising prices
Intermittent rains in Nashik district since October 19 delay kharif onion harvest; approximately 80% of kharif crops damaged by heavy September-October rainfall
Onion prices surge 26% at Lasalgaon APMC in 4 days (Rs 1,350 to Rs 1,710 per quintal) due to delayed kharif harvest; daily supply drops from 15,000 to 7,000-8,000 quintals due to rains
Wholesale prices at Lasalgaon reach Rs 1,710 per quintal but remain below production cost of Rs 1,800 per quintal; new kharif onions delayed until late November
Nashik onion prices rise 26% over 4 days to Rs 1,710 per quintal; kharif harvest delayed 4-6 weeks; supplies mainly from stored summer onion stock (March-April harvest)
Expected arrival of late kharif onion crops at Lasalgaon by last week of November; currently supplies limited to summer onions with 6-7 month shelf life
